I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  country  strategy  and  program1 (CSP)  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
includes  Capacity  Building  in  Water  Resources  in  a  Decentralized  Environment  technical 
assistance (TA).2 In March 2005, the Government of Indonesia (the Government) requested 
ADB to provide specific support for capacity building in the water resources sector to target 
(i) strengthening  the  capacity  for  integrated  water  resources  management  (IWRM); 
(ii) implementation of the new Water Law No. 7, 2004; (iii) follow-up on recommendations from 
the Capacity Building Project in the Water Resources Sector (CBWRS);3 and (iv) building the 
capacity of local government and local stakeholders under the recent policy of decentralization.   
 
2.  From 6 to 9 November 2007, ADB jointly hosted water financing program conference 
with the National Planning Development Agency (BAPPENAS) and Ministry of Public Works to 
boost  water  investments.  The  conference  conclusions  emphasized  the  importance  of 
significantly increasing water sector infrastructure investment in Indonesia. The Government 
again requested increased ADB financing and a higher level of TA support to capacity building 
development programs. 
 
3.  In November 2007, at the invitation of the Government, an ADB fact-finding mission 
visited Indonesia for consultations with the key water resources line agencies and sectoral 
stakeholders.  Based  on  these  consultations,  the  TA  was  formulated.4 The  Government 
confirmed its concurrence with the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, 
and  costs  and  financing  arrangements  of  the  proposed  TA.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Indonesia has abundant rainfall, resulting in some 3,100 billion cubic meters (m3) annual 
runoff or about 14,000 m3/person. However, countrywide averages misrepresent the severe 
water  stresses  found  in  Java,  which  is  home  to  120  million  people  (60%  of  Indonesia’s 
population, 83% of the industrial turnover, and 60% of rice production), where water availability 
is only 1,400 m3/person and under 500 m3/person in a number of key river basins. Java’s urban 
population will grow by 35 million–40 million by 2020, putting further stress on the environment 
and water services. In 2004, the United Nations reported that national access to safe water was 
estimated at 74% (urban 89%, rural 64%) and sanitation access 59% (urban 74%, rural 52%). 
However, Indonesia is unlikely to meet Millennium Development Goal targets, and is falling 
behind Southeast Asian water services delivery norms. 
 
5.  The Directorate General of Water Resources (DGWR) in the Ministry of Public Works is 
responsible for overall sector policy guidance, and provides national level management and 
implementation functions in the water resources sector. Independent water resources agencies 
(WRAs) provide services within the 40 provincial governments; a further 350 district level WRAs 
exist  within  decentralized  local  government  administrations.  In  addition,  133  hydrologically

defined river basin organizations (RBOs) provide development and asset management services 
for  in-stream  water  resources  management  in  river  basin  territories.  Subsector  legislation5 
(covering irrigation, rivers, swamps, coastal management, reservoirs, etc.) following Water Law 
No.  7  defines  the  roles  of  these  organizations.  This  legislation  takes  into  account  recent 
decentralization  policies  which  define,  in  global  terms,  the  roles  of  the  different  levels  of 
government and their fiscal responsibilities. To date, institutional assessments and diagnostics 
analysis of WRAs have not been undertaken in a systematic, rigorous, and comprehensive way 
to determine the effect of decentralization and water sector reforms on WRA capacity to deliver 
on their current responsibilities as mandated by law.  
 
6.  When analyzing current capacity development issues in the Indonesian water sector, it is 
important to consider these recent legislative changes. Administrative decentralization reform 
(Regional Autonomy Act No. 22, 1999, updated by Law No. 33, 2005); fiscal decentralization 
(Regional Fiscal Autonomy Act No. 25, 1999, updated by Law No. 34, 2005);6 and water sector 
reforms (Water Law No. 7, 2004) are mutually reinforcing both in concept and timing. They 
provide  an  excellent  opportunity  for  improved  water  resources  management  in  the  new 
decentralized environment. The water resources sector is gradually evolving from a highly 
centralized infrastructure development focus to a partially decentralized service delivery model. 
Institutional reform is ongoing. While the current labyrinth of WRA organizations remains is in its 
infancy, efforts by central and provincial governments to provide guidance and clarity have 
intensified since the issuance of the recent Water Law. Current efforts—focusing on role sharing 
between  different  levels  of  government  agencies,  developing  interagency  cooperation  and 
coordination, defining the roles of civil society organizations (CSOs), and elucidation of sector 
vis-à-vis  geographic  water  resources  management  models—provide  a  timely  window  of 
opportunity to support the Government in its capacity development efforts.  
 
7.  Indonesia’s  national  water  resources  policy  takes  a  holistic  IWRM  approach  to 
sustainable water resources management. The Medium Term Development Plan, 2004–2009, 
aims to address capacity constraints in the water resources sector, with a focus on capacity 
building. The water resources sector has been a major area of ADB assistance to Indonesia, 
totaling over $1.5 billion in loans and TA grants.7 Two key lessons from the ADB-funded CBWRS 
are that (i) the success of capacity building activities is highly dependent on strong commitment 
from the target individuals, managers and the involved institutions, the design stage of capacity 
building programs therefore need to allow sufficient time for adequate stakeholder participation; 
and  (ii) capacity  building  programs  are  long-term  commitments.  ADB  has  recently  gained 
valuable experience in addressing decentralization and providing capacity support to regional 
governments  in  Indonesia  through  the  Sustainable  Capacity  Building  for  Decentralization 
Project (SCBDP).8 This project was designed to develop institutional capacity to (i) deliver 
efficient public services in accordance with minimum service standards, (ii) maintain essential 
publicly managed facilities, and (iii) promote equitable economic development. Lessons from the 
SCBDP will be applied to diagnostic assessments of WRAs operating in the decentralized 
environment.

8.  In 2007, ADB provided TA to DGWR for pilot testing a diagnostic analysis approach 
within Citarum River Basin Organization (Appendix 2). Outputs confirmed the need to (i) clarify 
the  mandate  and  specific  responsibilities  of  the  organization,  including  role-sharing 
arrangements  with  other  WRAs;  (ii)  strengthen  management  and  leadership  skills; 
(iii) strengthen  staff  capacities  in  nonengineering  disciplines;  (iv)  develop  networking  with 
regional WRAs and CSOs; and (v) provide more budget for routine operations. An overriding 
lesson was that while many officials (regional planners and policy makers, local WRA managers, 
and central Government) talk of capacity building, a basic understanding of the real capacity 
gaps is missing and capacity strengthening plans have not been adequately prepared. Further 
use of the diagnostic process on a wider group of RBOs and regional WRAs will provide central 
oversight agencies with a better overall picture of nationwide water sector capacity constraints 
in the decentralized environment.  
 
9.  The CBWRS was intended to be the first of a series of interventions to address the 
capacity  concerns  of  the  water  resources  sector  and initiate  a long-term  capacity  building 
process (footnote 3). The capacity building road is long, and the CBWRS was the first broad 
attempt to assist the Government to build effective multi-stakeholder water resources capacity 
at various levels of government. The TA will highlight post-Water Law capacity gaps in a 
number  of  RBOs  and  WRAs  to  provide  a  better  understanding  of  current  sector  capacity 
constraints. Based on this understanding, it will prepare preliminary designs for a longer-term 
capacity  development  strategy  and  support  program  to  continue  the  long-term  partnership 
between ADB and the Government in the water sector. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be to contribute to the environmental sustainability of natural 
resources in Indonesia. The primary outcome of the TA will be improved governance and water 
resources management among decentralized water resources stakeholders (Appendix 1).   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will build on previous and ongoing ADB/government capacity building initiatives 
and support, and it will complement ongoing and proposed ADB loans in the water resources 
sector.9 It will support BAPPENAS and DGWR in the development of national capacity building 
processes for the water sector by facilitating these organizations to lead: (i) phase 1, pilot 
testing  of  participatory  capacity  development  action  plans  (CDAPs);  and  (ii)  phase  2, 
development of a countrywide capacity building strategy. 
 
 
 
                                                 
9 The lending pipeline of projects includes the Integrated Citarum Water Resources Management Investment 
Program and Flood Management in Selected River Basins Project. The ongoing Participatory Irrigation Sector 
Project (ADB. 2003. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan 
to the Republic of Indonesia for the Participatory Irrigation Sector Project. Manila.) supports a participatory 
approach  to  management  of  irrigation  and  water  resources  in  a  decentralized  administrative  and  fiscal 
environment. The Earthquake and Tsunami Emergency Support Project (ADB. 2005. Report and Recommendation 
of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Grant to the Republic  of Indonesia for the Earthquake 
and  Tsunami  Emergency  Support  Project.  Manila.)  irrigation  component  supports  rehabilitation  of  irrigation 
schemes over a total service area of about 70,000 hectares.

4   
(1)  Phase 1: Pilot Testing of Capacity Development Action Plans 
   
12.  The TA will review experience gained from recent capacity development initiatives with 
CSOs,  WRAs,  and  regional  governments.  Building  on  these  experiences,  it  will  pilot  test 
capacity development performance assessments and diagnostic analysis techniques in five 
RBOs; eight provincial WRAs, and sixteen district WRAs.10 The output of phase 1 will be 
CDAPs for the selected regional water resource organizations. 
  
13.  In phase 1, the TA will develop the capacity of the selected regional WRAs to prepare 
CDAPs. Capacity building support to water sector stakeholders will include (i) the provision of 
technical support and targeted training to WRAs and CSOs; (ii) studies and working group 
problem analysis, and the development of capacity development process skills; (iii) expanding 
public  awareness  in  IWRM;  (iv)  increasing  private  and  civil  society  involvement  in  IWRM; 
(v) undertaking peer reviews of CDAPs across WRAs; and (vi) preparing guidelines for the 
production of further CDAPs, based on experience gained during the pilot testing exercise. 
 
(2)  Phase  2:  Prepare  a  Capacity  Building  Strategy  for  RBOs  and  Regional 
WRAs  
 
14.  Building on phase 1 outputs, phase 2 will prepare an initial assessment of countrywide 
capacity development needs for RBOs and WRAs (para. 4). This will include analysis of (i) the 
CDAPs prepared under phase 1, comparing the results of  these assessments to other studies 
on the capacity of regional WRAs; (ii) staff and logistical resource requirements for model 
representative RBOs and WRAs; (iii) nationwide estimates of the number of model RBOs and 
WRAs required to manage the water sector in the decentralized environment; and (iv) the 
overall  capacity  gap  for  RBOs  and  WRAs  extrapolated  to  estimate  countrywide  long-term 
capacity development requirements. Based on this analysis, and assessments of appropriate 
capacity support mechanisms, a capacity building strategy for RBOs and regional WRAs will be 
prepared.  
 
15.  The TA will support working groups (para. 18) to enable inclusive processes in the 
formulation of the strategy and to facilitate a better understanding in the oversight agencies of 
real capacity constraints in the sector. It will also support the preparation of the capacity building 
water resources sector cluster TA proposed in the CSP. 
   
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. ADB will make 
available a grant of $850,000 and the Government will provide $75,000 for the proposed TA 
total of $925,000. Government input will comprise in-kind contributions for counterpart staff and 
office  accommodation  for  the  project  team;  and  DGWR  will  provide  partial  funding  for 
counterpart staff and logistics, a subregional workshop in 2008, and a quarterly workshop in 
2009. DGWR will ensure that the 2009 annual work programs for the Participatory Irrigation 
Sector Project (PISP) and other relevant programs include activities supporting implementation 
of CDAPs. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 3.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  18  months  from  the  date  of  TA  approval  and 
concurrence of the Government. DGWR will be the Executing Agency for the TA and will 
coordinate activities with ADB on behalf of the Implementing Agencies (BAPPENAS, DGWR, 
and WRAs). ADB will mobilize a team of consultants (15 person-months international and 
85 person-months  national)  to  support  implementation  of  the  TA.  The  consultants  will  be 
engaged by ADB using individual recruitment and quality-based selection11 for the firm, with the 
biodata technical proposal, in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, 
as amended from time to time). Outline terms of reference, together with an indicative list of 
consultants, are in Appendix 4. Any equipment purchased through consultant contracts will be 
undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time) and transferred to DGWR at the end of the TA. 
 
18.  The  TA  will  be  led  by  a  national  consulting  firm,  forming  an  association  with 
nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs).  The  firm  will  be  supported  by  individually  recruited 
oversight and specialist consultants. The proposed services allow for a number of “on call” 
experts  (national  and/or  international)  to  assist  in  enhancing  knowledge  and  strengthening 
individuals/ organizations in the sector. The Government and CSO working groups will be 
established as a forum for debate and dialogue. Quarterly coordination workshops will be held 
to share the development of the TA outputs, and ensure project outcomes are disseminated 
efficiently through line agencies and stakeholders. Tripartite meetings will be held at least three 
times: at the end of the inception phase, after 6 months, and at TA completion. In addition to the 
consultant’s  routine  progress  reports,  working  group  meetings  will  provide  a  vehicle  for 
dissemination of TA outputs, together with a final TA workshop. 
   
19.  The Implementing Agencies will establish effective mechanisms to engage with civil 
society  to  ensure  stakeholder  participation  in  the  development  of  CDAPs.  To  support  the 
process, the TA will use working groups and peer review processes in addition to traditional 
consulting services and NGO facilitation activities.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $850,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Indonesia for Capacity Building in Water Resources in a Decentralized 
Environment, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

capacity  building  impacts  requested  by  the  Government  and  required  to  support  significant  ongoing  ADB 
operations in Indonesia, are delivered.

8  Appendix 2 
CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT AND CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT ACTION PLANS 
 
A.  Capacity Development 
 
1.  Capacity Development Process1 
1.  The capacity development process has three essential phases: 
 
(i)  Performance  analysis.  Identifying  performance  gaps  that  the  organization 
wishes to address. 
(ii)  Capacity  diagnostic  analysis.  Identifying  the  factors  leading  to  the 
organization’s gaps. 
(iii)  Strategy development. Based on the diagnostic analysis, developing strategies 
to address factors that constrain capacity. 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) evaluations of a number of capacity development 
technical  assistance  (TA)  projects  indicate  that  such  a  systematic  capacity  development 
process is often not followed because of (i) development partners’ bias toward pre-favored 
interventions (e.g., training, scholarships, technology transfer, equipment purchase, etc.); and 
(ii) lack of capacity development capability of consulting firms working on capacity development 
programs.  Capacity  development  investments  will  not  be  optimum  unless  there  is  holistic, 
systematic, and rigorous prior analysis of capacity led by and involving key stakeholders in the 
organization.  
 
3.  The capacity development process (strategies, pace, and sequencing) must be led by 
the organization, with facilitation from outside (consultants) where assistance is needed. The 
consultant  facilitator  can  provide  a  road  map,  help  avoid  barriers,  provide  monitoring  and 
feedback, and support experience from lessons from similar experiences. Training and using 
peer reviewers from similar organizations can be cost-effective and add learning to the process. 
Internal  ownership,  fostered  from  leading  and  participating  in  performance  and  diagnostic 
analyses, will lead to sustainability.  
 
2.  Performance Analysis 
4.  Capacity development was defined by the United Nations Development Programme in 
1997 as  
 
The process by which individuals, groups, organizations, institutions and 
societies increase their abilities: to perform functions solve problems and 
achieve objectives; to understand and deal with their development need 
in a broader context and in a sustainable manner.  
 
5.  Performance analysis is the first step in a capacity development intervention: 
 
(i)  What is the assigned mandate?  
(ii)  Are  expected  results  clear  (outputs-products,  services,  deliverables,  and 
outcomes-benefits achieved, impacts)? 
(iii)  What is the level of performance (service quality and quantity)? 
                                                 
1 The conceptual framework for capacity development and diagnostics will be reviewed and updated during the

(iv)  Are there performance gaps? 
 
6.  There is a tendency not to ask these questions. However, in the drive to introduce 
results based management and routine performance analysis in Indonesia, such questions are 
becoming more common. Arguably, the most crucial step in the capacity development process 
is  defining  a  results  framework,  establishing  performance  monitoring,  and  developing 
information systems to obtain and monitor results for future organizational improvements.  
 
3.  Capacity Diagnostic Analysis 
7.  The diagnostic process is not complex. It involves assessing why performance gaps 
exist  and  the  analysis  can  only  be  carried  out  effectively  from  within  an  organization.  A 
participatory, interactive approach to the analysis is required, with skilled process expertise 
assisting  managers  and  staff.  A  cause-effect  tree  analysis  is  a  practical,  effective,  and 
recommended technique.  
 
4.  Strategy Development 
8.  There  is  no  standard  strategy,  proven  design,  or  standard  template  for  successful 
capacity development. However, there are well-grounded principles and a broad road map 
(Figure A2). If carefully followed, these will increase the chances of implementing a sound, 
efficient, and sustainable capacity development strategy.

B.  Capacity Development Action Plans  
1.  Preparation Process 
9.  Capacity development action plans (CDAPs) for water resources management will help 
governments define their capacity building strategy, detailed programs, and required funding. 
The main elements of a CDAP are (i) framework (capacity development policy, water resources 
program  strategy,  and  planning  performance  targets);  (ii)  institutional  strengthening 
(organizational,  legal,  and  regulatory  environment  for  improved  governance);  (iii)  human 
resources management (systems and methods); (iv) human resources development (training 
and  education);  (v)  financing,  budgeting,  and  planning  (sustainable  systems);  and 
(vi) implementation and monitoring mechanisms. 
 
10.  A CDAP must cover a sufficiently long period of implementation to deliver meaningful 
benefits. It will be designed as a medium-term action plan, broken down into annual action 
agendas and investment and recurrent budgets. The process of CDAP formulation, as adopted 
under the Sustainable Capacity Building for Decentralization Project (SCBDP)2, is summarized 
as follows.  
(i)  Needs assessment and diagnostic analysis. The local CDAP team will (a) 
map  out  existing  capacity  problems  and  priority  actions,  and  (b)  develop 
strategies in six main areas referred to in para. 11 and on gender. This is done 
through  intensive  consultation  between  various  agencies,  civil  society 
organizations (CSOs), and consumers; and is observed by the media. 
(ii)  Drafting of relevant components (strategy development) of the CDAP. This 
includes  scheduling  short-  and  medium-term  measures  and  the  provision  of 
technical backstopping. 
(iii)  Present the draft CDAP for consultation among relevant agencies at district level. 
(iv)  Develop the CDAP budget through consultation between the CDAP team, local 
financial agency, and local parliament budgetary commission—identifying local 
and external budgetary contributions. 
(v)  The draft CDAP is reviewed by the support team at national level.  
(vi)  The CDAP is legalized by local parliament as part of the regional strategic plan.

Republic  of Indonesia for the Sustainable Capacity Building for Decentralization. Manila.

Appendix 2  11 
C.  Capacity Development Lessons 
1.  Capacity Development in the Indonesian Decentralized Environment 
 
11.  Capacity building needs assessments for local governments and legislatures3, carried 
out between November 1999 and October 2000, concluded that a capacity building strategy to 
implement  the  current  decentralization  policy  in  Indonesia  should  start  with  seven  major 
elements. 
 
(i)  Improvement of the central Government’s information and dissemination strategy. 
(ii)  Preparation of a non-prescriptive “positive list” of local government functions. 
(iii)  Preparation of model regional regulations in key policy areas to ease the burden 
of the regions to put in place a multitude of new regulations within a very short 
period of time. 
(iv)  Review of sectoral regulations to ensure that the sectoral regulatory framework is 
in accordance with laws no. 22 and 25, 1999, and their implementing regulations. 
(v)  Clarification of the mechanism of transferring central government civil servants to 
the regions and of the arrangements to merge central government institutions 
with regional government institutions. 
(vi)  Improvement of coordination between central government agencies involved in 
the decentralization policy.  
(vii)  Focus on demand-driven capacity building programs that central government 
agencies can support with a mix of tools and instruments.  
 
12.  This assessment resulted in a national capacity building framework that emphasizes the 
need for involvement of the public and private sector. It also recommends eight policy clusters 
for government action and external support: (i) regulatory framework, (ii) institutional reform 
measures,  (iii)  human  resources  management,  (iv)  regional  financial  management,  (v) 
strengthening civil society and regional parliaments, (vi) participatory regional planning, (vii) 
local  economic  development,  and  (viii)  managing  the  transition  period.  In  addition,  it 
recommends interventions at the system, institutional, and individual levels. 
 
2.  Capacity Development in Water Resources 
13.  Lessons  from  recent  project  completion  report  and  project  performance  evaluation 
report4 reviews of the CBWRS project include the following. 
(i)  In-depth  understanding  of  organization  characteristics,  strengths,  and 
weaknesses leads to a more tailored approach to the activity design and program 
distribution.

Technical Assistance Grants to the Republic of Indonesia for the Community and Local Government Support 
Sector Development Program. Manila.

12  Appendix 2 
(ii)  The use of centralized projects to support capacity building activities in local 
government  can  be  effective,  but  implementing  arrangements  and  fund  flow 
mechanisms should be carefully designed in a participatory manner. 
(iii)  Classical training has limited application. A varied form of on-the-job training for 
trainees is generally more beneficial and better value, although it is more time-
consuming and expensive, and requires skilled delivery.  
(iv)  Introduction of new management systems (e.g., results oriented management) 
should be carefully combined or integrated to enhance existing planning and 
management systems and local wisdom. Often, new techniques can best be 
simply used to enhance and develop existing practices since poor translation of 
new ideas can cause suspicion and nonacceptance.  
(v)  Public  awareness  campaigns  have  proved  to  be  successful,  low-cost,  large 
impact initiatives. 
(vi)  The ability of projects to adjust when challenged by external factors is important 
to increase project impact. Close monitoring and flexibility by the Government 
and ADB optimizes use of project resources. 
(vii)   As part of a holistic approach to capacity building, careful consideration should 
be given to increasing outsourcing of activities and strengthening the capacity of 
local  consulting  nongovernment  and  CSOs  (nongovernment  organizations, 
universities, etc.). 
(viii)  Capacity building projects often focus on easy-to-monitor activities and outputs 
(training days, equipment purchase) rather than less tangible outcomes (quality 
of hydrological databases, implementation of effective river basin management) 
which reflect increased capacity. There is a need to continue to search for, and 
focus on, the real impact indicators. 
(ix)  The success of capacity building is highly dependent on strong commitment from 
the  target  individuals,  managers,  and  institutions.  Stakeholder  ownership  is 
essential during project design, with the understanding that capacity building 
programs are long-term commitments. 
 
14.  Specific follow-up actions agreed between ADB and the Government during post-project 
evaluations of the CBWRS included the following: (i) developing systems for improved access to  
knowledge-based systems; (ii) the requirements for further development of human resources 
management, including manpower planning, performance appraisals, promotion, and incentives 
management will be assessed; (iii) central government funding to the water resources master’s 
program  will  continue  in  accordance  with  needs-based  assessments;  (iv)  ADB  and  the 
Directorate  General  of  Water  Resources  (DGWR)  will  jointly  review  the  Water  Resources 
Development Center activities included in the recently signed Participatory Irrigation Sector 
Project5,  and  adjust  activities  to  take  into  account  lessons  from  the  CBWRS  and  current 
requirements of the Water Resources Data Center, if appropriate; (v) increased training and 
support for hydrological data collection, data processing, and management information systems 
should be provided to provincial water resources services; and (vi) ADB should remain an 
engaged and supportive partner to the Government’s continued efforts to raise capacity in the 
water resources sector. ADB and the Government should carefully review the need for follow-up 
programs and capacity building needs on all ongoing projects during routine portfolio reviews.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The primary objective of the technical assistance (TA) is to improve governance and 
water resources management among decentralized water resources stakeholders.1 
 
2.  The TA will be executed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and will be implemented 
by the Directorate General of Water Resources (DGWR) with coordination and monitoring from 
the National Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS).2 The TA consultants will be based in 
offices of government agencies at national, provincial, and district level. The main consulting 
team will be a national firm or a consortium of national firms and will be established in DGWR. 
The  TA  consulting  services  will  be  implemented  over  12  months.  Figure  A4  presents  the 
structure of consulting and nongovernment organization (NGO) support services. Table A4 
illustrates an outline work program.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
3.  The TA will comprise two phases: (i) phase 1: pilot testing of capacity development 
action plans, and (ii)  phase  2:  preparing  a  capacity  building  strategy  for  river  basin 
organizations (RBOs) and regional water resources agencies (WRAs).  
 
4.  The main outcomes of the TA will be a greater ability of national and selected regional 
agencies, and services providers, to pilot test performance and diagnostic analysis and prepare 
sustainable capacity development strategies based on the diagnostic analysis.  
 
C.  Consultant Terms of Reference  
 
1.  International Consultants 
5.  The core international team shall consist of expertise in capacity development processes, 
monitoring  of  capacity  development  programs,  and  institutional  and  water  resources 
management—hired as a core team through the individual recruitment process. The core team 
shall visit Indonesia on a quarterly basis to (i) provide oversight and monitoring, training, and 
guidance  to  the  TA  national  consultants,  national  and  regional  WRAs  and  civil  society 
organization (CSO) stakeholders; and (ii) monitor TA implementation, with a focus on long-term 
strengthening of water management in a decentralized environment. Specific guidance and 
support will be given to oversight agencies (DGWR/BAPPENAS). Key tasks are shown below. 
 
a.  Capacity Development Process and Monitoring Specialist  
6.  The capacity development process and monitoring specialist will (i) support ADB in the 
overall  work  program  and  staffing  management  and  implementation  monitoring  of  the  TA; 
(ii) ensure that international and national consulting/NGO inputs and line agency contributions 
are effectively meshed with technical and institutional aspects of the TA, and are logically linked 
in a timely manner and proceed smoothly; (iii) ensure that working groups are active and 
productive; (iv) ensure that decentralized regional governments are selected and participate in a 
transparent efficient manner in TA activities; (v) coordinate with Participatory Irrigation Sector 
Project3 and  other  water  resources  capacity  building  programs;  (vi)  develop  and  support 
benchmarking procedures and the peer review process for implementation; and (vii) monitor 
and report on TA progress. The consultant will work under the technical guidance of the ADB 
project officer (7.0 person-months). 
 
b.  Institutional Specialist   
7.  The  institutional  specialist  will  (i)  support  the  capacity  development  process  and 
monitoring specialist consultant; (ii) provide guidance on assessment processes for (a) the 
mandates  of  central  level  agencies  and  cooperation  mechanisms;  (b)  the  resources  and 
processes employed in the sector; (c) the newly decentralized system (including questions 
related to functional and fiscal decentralization: have the functions assigned to different levels of 
government been clearly spelled out?); (d) demarcation of the new roles of central, provincial, 
kabupaten (district) and/or kota (city) governments, and other stakeholders in water resources 
development  and  management;  (e)  ensuring  that  functional  assignments  are  clear  and 
consistent with the decentralization legislation; (iii) provide guidance on capacity development

assessment and diagnostic processing and capacity development action plans (CDAPs); (iv) 
review legal regulations and their effect on WRA responsibilities; and (v) monitor and report on 
TA progress. The consultant will work under the technical guidance of the capacity development 
process and monitoring specialist consultant, and the ADB project officer (3.5 person-months).  
  
c.  Integrated Water Resources Management Specialist   
8.  The integrated water resources/asset management specialist will (i) support the capacity 
development  process  and  monitoring  specialist  consultant;  (ii)  provide  guidance  on  water 
resources development and management roles and responsibilities of WRA organizations and 
other stakeholders; (iii) review the effect of the recent Water Law and decentralization on 
integrated water resources management (IWRM), irrigation, and flood management activities; 
(iv) provide support to asset management programs and the monitoring and benchmarking 
initiatives; and (v) monitor and report on TA progress. The consultant will work under the 
technical guidance of the capacity development process and monitoring specialist consultant, 
and the ADB project officer (2.5 person-months).  
 
d.  Other International Inputs   
9.  A total of 2 person-months of international consultant input will be mobilized as required. 
A list of indicative consultant positions (none-core national and international) is in Figure A4. 
The consultants will work under the technical direction of the national team leader, supported by 
the international core team (2.0 person-months). 
 
2.  National Consultant Inputs 
10.  A total of 85 person-months of national consultant inputs will be mobilized to support the 
activities under the TA. A list of indicative consultant positions is in Figure A4. The consultants 
will  work  under  the  technical  direction  of  a  national  team  leader,  with  support  from  the 
international core team. The national consultants’ core team will provide the main training and 
facilitation services—supporting working groups (or change management teams) within selected 
government water resources agencies targeted for the CDAPs.  
 
D.  Implementing Arrangements, Reporting, and Deliverables 
 
11.  The consultants will work under the direction of the ADB project officer. Three periodic 
reports will be produced by the national consultant in conjunction with the core international 
team: (i) an inception report about 6 weeks after commencement of the TA, (ii) an interim report 
at about 6 months, and (iii) a final report at the end of the TA. In addition, special studies and 
reports, and CDAPs will be prepared.
